answers.answer: Hi. I was induced as well but it was at 40 weeks. I was nervous at first. Basically, you check into the hospital and they start giving you small amounts of pitocin**spellcheck starts contractions for you. As the hours rolled by they increased the dosage little by little. I checked in about 7pm. The next morning, 6am they turned the dose all the way up and started manually dialating me. After about 30 minutes of the contractions (because they have to let the contractions mature first), I was given an epidural. I started pushing at 1:35pm and had him at 1:51pm. It wasn't a bad experience at all.

Well,if you are scheduled to have an induced labor,it is because it is necessary.i had my first born through the same.i would say it was easy for me,because it was my first time & I was expecting worse.i didn't use epdro to manage the pain . my advice is, don't be scared, be positive & all will be fine. Remember to be calm . breath through your mouth in and out . don't scream, because you need to save that energy for pushing . it will be well!
By the way, that was my first child at 35 years old though I was told I'd never have children. He will be a year old November 7th and I'm 5 weeks pregnant now. Good luck.

I have gestational diabetes also and I'm due November 14 and I was told if my water doesn't break on its own I will be induce by my due date I'm also nervous but I'm glad at least I know I'm not going over but I'm also hoping my water breaks on its own
How far a long you cuz I have gestational diabetes and my midwife has said anything about me needing to be induced

@bsBritney23, I'm 37 weeks, I'll be 39 weeks whenever they induce me. And same, she didn't say anything about me needing to be induced until just now - even after my GD diagnosis, we had been planning on a natural birth so this threw me for a loop.@Patriciaaa02, ditto! I wanted him to come on his own, even embraced the idea that he'd be overdue; I was prepared for that. This, though I feel like I should be ecstatic, I'm not. I've heard and read about way too much horror stories about how induction is not only super hard on your body but that they often can lead to emergency c-sections, and I had wanted to avoid that at all costs! I'm not liking this and feeling like my wishes are basically being disregarded, especially as my midwife didn't even give me a valid reason for why she wanted to induce me.@HzAngel, thank you for your input! Did they induce you and then send you home to labor, or did they admit you into the hospital to monitor you? And that's basically what I was told with our LO, that it would either be very difficult for me to conceive even with medical intervention if I managed to successfully carry a many at all. There's so many thoughts going through my head right now!
Hi!! They admitted me for inducement. They won't dare send you back home.Once you check in its show time!! :-)

Are they doing stress test on your baby to make sure he/she is doing OK I talked to my midwife today just cuz of your post and she said she would only inducie like 3 days early she doesn't want me going much over 40 and I told her I didn't want to have a Halloween baby.. Are ur sugars good

They do weekly stress tests and she's remarked that he reacts beautifully to them, and he isn't too big for his gestational age. Sugars have been excellent, within target so I truly have no idea why she feels that it's necessary

I just understand why if he's healthy and I'm healthy, why he can't just come on his own. To my knowledge there is absolutely no other medical reason why an induction is necessary aside from me being a gestational diabetic.

Ask lots of questions. Likely there is a good reason for it most doctors don't like to induce. BUT it is important  for you to remember it is ALWAYS your choice. She doesn't get to decide it's your baby and your body.

only reason why i was induced was due to low placental fluid.I had gd . with all 3 I'm 31 weeks now with my third.first one was forceps delivery.second emergency c sect.both induced.i am hoping for natural delivery.vbac it's been 4 years since my last baby.i hated the c sect recovery was horrid compared to vag.delivery.

I have GD too and I will induce around 39 weeks if I haven't gone in labor before. Even with well manage blood sugar, diabetes might age your placenta and baby will have lesss nutrients and oxygen. To make sure baby is in good conditions for birth they induce. You can still have a meds free vaginal birth excluding inducing drugs of course.
I have gestational diabetes too and my Dr says probably going to induce me at 37 weeks or 38 weeks. But I also have hypertension.

I got induced at 39 weeks at 10am  due to my water breaking but not dilating fast enough. It was a short process.  They put me on an iv and got my Pitocin started.  They started with small doses then once my contractions started hurting more and got closer they turned it up until I reached 4cm (2pm) I got my epidural.  Kept turning up the Pitocin until I reached 10 cm (1:10am next morning)  and they had me push.  Pushed for 36 minutes.  Gave birth at 1:46am. It went smoother than I thought it would be. Just stay calm,  relax and breath! Best of luck!

question: So ironically after posting a long, venting post on here today at my weekly checkup my midwife informed me that due to my gestational diabetes that she was going to schedule me to be induced in the 26th. I'm terrified of this, I never wanted to be induced, and frankly don't understand why it's necessary if my baby isn't showing any signs of distreas in the womb, but I feel like she isn't giving me much of a choice... Is it advisable to ask the other attending physician if he thinks it will be necessary, and if it is, are there any other Mommies who have undergone the induction process that can give me an idea what to expect?
title: what to expect for induction
